item.title: 10 Great Articles about Go
item.author: Andy Rees
item.description:
The fastest way to mastery in any field is to emulate expertise of those at the top of their field. With that in mind, I have collected a few great links and articles that will catapult you into their esteemed company in no time at all.

  1. Building Web Apps with Go

    Learn how to build and deploy web applications with Go. A useful overview from the creator of Martini and Negroni.

    Read

  2. Go Concurrency Patterns

    Go’s concurrency primitives make it easy to construct streaming data pipelines that make efficient use of I/O and multiple CPUs. This article presents examples of such pipelines, highlights subtleties that arise when operations fail, and introduces techniques for dealing with failures cleanly.

    article

  3. Go Training Classes by Ardan Studios

    The Ardan Labs Go Bootcamp is a 3 day class providing a comprehensive and idiomatic view of the Go programming language. The class covers topics ranging from language syntax, OOP, concurrency, channels, testing, debugging and more. Great for anyone interested in getting a jump start on learning Go or wanting to understand more about the language and internals. But if you can’t make it to the course, the code and course notes are available here.

    notes

  4. Twelve Go Best Practices, Francesc Campoy Flores


    slides

  5. Whispering Gophers, Network programming in Go, by Andrew Gerrand & Francesc Campoy. A great code lab that demonstrates network programming in Go.

    slides

  6. 10 things you (probably) don’t know about Go, Andrew Gerrand

    slides

  7. Go: code that grows with grace, Andrew Gerrand

    Go: code that grows with grace from Øredev Conference on Vimeo.

    slides

  8. A Tour of the Go Programming Language, Russ Cox


  9. Go for Gophers, Andrew Gerrand


    slides

  10. JSON, interfaces, and go generate, Francesc Campoy


    slides

item.title: How to start using Go
item.author: Andy Rees
item.description:
Go is a fast strongly typed, garbage collected modern language developed by Google and the open-source community. It can be deployed as a single binary and can easily cross compile for other platforms.

Here are a few handy links an tutorials to get you started

  1. The Official Google, web based tour of the Go Programming Language. To get started with it, you don’t even need to have the tools installed. The following link provides an interactive web-based tutorial, and even has labs.

    tour.golang.org

  2. Installation of the Go toolset. When you are ready to give it a go on your own system, this guide wil help you get set up.

    Go Installation

  3. Getting started with Go

  4. Effective Go way. How to write idiomatic code the Go way.

    effective Go

  5. Go By Example. This site has some great code examples of the basics of the language.

    Go By Example
